linkTarget.anchoringText: Casabe has been under waterflooding since 1980. Injection rates declined dramatically after 10 years struggling with the injection vertical profile which allow only 3.4% of recovery factor due to waterflooding as shown in Fig. 1.

Vertical efficiency was improved from 20% to 50% with the implementation of selective completion for the entire field. See the last log track in Fig. 2 how selective completion change the injection profile in the same injection well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: See how the injection profile have changed in the last log due to selective completion. Flow regulators allow to control injection for high permeability zones.

formatted-caption.caption-text: See how the injection profile have changed in the last log due to selective completion. Flow regulators allow to control injection for high permeability zones.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Oil Saturation Map. Example for one layer sand are over 50% of So

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Saturation Map. Example for one layer sand are over 50% of So

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Excessive co-production of water in the evaluated Block at the end of the year 2012, notice how the oil curve decrease when water increase

formatted-caption.caption-text: Excessive co-production of water in the evaluated Block at the end of the year 2012, notice how the oil curve decrease when water increase

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Use of flow assessing tools in Casabe. Notice the use of technology started after production begin to decline

formatted-caption.caption-text: Use of flow assessing tools in Casabe. Notice the use of technology started after production begin to decline

linkTarget.anchoringText: ILTs represent the basis for the evaluation of injection allocation in Casabe. In each well the aim is to have at least 3 ILTs per year. When a negative event like abrupt high BSW is identified in a producer, an ILT is run in each injector in the entire pattern. Water flow regulators have failed on a regular basis and abnormal high rates are found like shown in Fig. 6 where two regulators are in 390% and 2247% over injecting generating injectivities of 38 bbl/ft and 107 bbl/ft respectively being the injectivity recommended for this sands no more than 10 bbl/ft.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: ILT results showing failure of regulation in Mandrels number 6 and 8

formatted-caption.caption-text: ILT results showing failure of regulation in Mandrels number 6 and 8

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 7 illustrates an example of the information obtained from “swabbing”. A portion of a well log with perforations are shown in the central track. Due to the flowing condition the packers were located from bottom to top identifying three flowing zones. In the boxes next to the identified flowing zones are the lab results shown. Considering costs it was not possible to continue evaluating individual layers this was therefore done in groups by correlation with injection zones. In this case the upper zone produce 7% of sediments with 85% of water cut. Based on the amount of sediments the zone was closed from the injectors.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Three flowing zones found from “swabbing”. Upper zone identified as the sand producer according lab results from fluid samples taken for each zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Three flowing zones found from “swabbing”. Upper zone identified as the sand producer according lab results from fluid samples taken for each zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: PLT results showing layer A3 with 100% of water cut

formatted-caption.caption-text: PLT results showing layer A3 with 100% of water cut

linkTarget.anchoringText: With this information the A3 was isolated in the entire injection pattern resulting in an increment of oil production and a reduction in water cut as shown in Figure 9. But it was not possible to identify which of the four injectors caused the channeling. The neighbor producers were not affected by closing A3 which means the preferential flow is only toward one producer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Water reduction after isolation of layer A3

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water reduction after isolation of layer A3

linkTarget.anchoringText: A pattern was selected in Block 3 (Fig. 10) to inject tracers in two layers (A2 and A2i) of four injector wells, eight different tracers in total. From the monitoring of breakthrough of tracers in first line producers (Fig. 11) it was confirmed that preferential flow in layer A2i was taking place. The breakthrough took place in less than 7 days and almost 90% of the tracer mass was recovered (Fig. 12). This represents an almost total recirculation in one layer. In terms of conductivity it can be said that 20% of the pore volume conduct 60% of the total flow (Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Chemical tracer injection in a five spot pattern.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Chemical tracer injection in a five spot pattern.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A pattern was selected in Block 3 (Fig. 10) to inject tracers in two layers (A2 and A2i) of four injector wells, eight different tracers in total. From the monitoring of breakthrough of tracers in first line producers (Fig. 11) it was confirmed that preferential flow in layer A2i was taking place. The breakthrough took place in less than 7 days and almost 90% of the tracer mass was recovered (Fig. 12). This represents an almost total recirculation in one layer. In terms of conductivity it can be said that 20% of the pore volume conduct 60% of the total flow (Fig. 13).

From the monitoring of breakthrough of tracers in first line producers (Fig. 11) it was confirmed that preferential flow in layer A2i was taking place. The breakthrough took place in less than 7 days and almost 90% of the tracer mass was recovered (Fig. 12). This represents an almost total recirculation in one layer. A pattern was selected in Block 3 (Fig. 10) to inject tracers in two layers (A2 and A2i) of four injector wells, eight different tracers in total. From the monitoring of breakthrough of tracers in first line producers (Fig. 11) it was confirmed that preferential flow in layer A2i was taking place. The breakthrough took place in less than 7 days and almost 90% of the tracer mass was recovered (Fig. 12). This represents an almost total recirculation in one layer. In terms of conductivity it can be said that 20% of the pore volume conduct 60% of the total flow (Fig. 13).

Usual evaluation of water saturation is done from resistivity logs but in a field with more than 30 years of waterflooding history with injection of sweet water, it is common to identify cases like Fig. 14, where resistivity logs run in the same layer in a lapse of 19 years show how salinity affect measurements.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Time lapse resistivity logs correspondingto years 1993 and 2012 shows and abnormal change

formatted-caption.caption-text: Time lapse resistivity logs correspondingto years 1993 and 2012 shows and abnormal change

linkTarget.anchoringText: Low sweep efficiency due to high permeability flow paths is evident from the analysis of Figures 15 and 16. Fig. 15 shows a layer with water saturation (Sw) near to irreducible water saturation (Swi) which lead us to roughly interpret as a good candidate to open for production according petrophysics.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Interpreted water cut from resistivity logs indicate Sw near to Swi for sand A1d. Predicted water cut is almost zero.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Interpreted water cut from resistivity logs indicate Sw near to Swi for sand A1d. Predicted water cut is almost zero.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Low sweep efficiency due to high permeability flow paths is evident from the analysis of Figures 15 and 16. Fig. 15 shows a layer with water saturation (Sw) near to irreducible water saturation (Swi) which lead us to roughly interpret as a good candidate to open for production according petrophysics.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Interpreted Sw from saturation log indicate 20-70% of Sw for sand A1d. Predicted water cut is 100%. Example of fluid fingering.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Interpreted Sw from saturation log indicate 20-70% of Sw for sand A1d. Predicted water cut is 100%. Example of fluid fingering.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 17 shows an individual example of the period of time a producer was closed while evaluations were made to identify the conformance problem. Notice the high pressure in red as indicator of strong communication between producer and injector. The work here was to identify what layer is channeled.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Production curve of a well with conformance problems.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production curve of a well with conformance problems.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 18 shows an example of what is being done in Casabe in an individual block. See in black how water was being reduced since the last months of 2014 in 21 producers with conformance problems paying special attention to the oil curve which was maintain despite of total fluids reduction

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Production behavior of 21 wells treated by conformance problems

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production behavior of 21 wells treated by conformance problems
